docs.abstract: Nicholas D Kristof Op-Ed column describes his failed attempt to obtain protest permit in Beijing to test assertion that Chinese government would allow public demonstrations in designated areas during Olympic Games; notes that although process was charade of endless bureaucracy, it still represents progress in that law implicitly acknowledges legitimacy of protest, and trickle of Chinese applicants indicates that fear of government is waning (M)
docs.snippet: Chinese officials explained that so long as protesters obtained approval in advance, demonstrations would be allowed. So I decided to test the system.
docs.lead_paragraph: To put a smiley face on its image during the Olympics, the Chinese government set aside three ''protest zones'' in Beijing. Officials explained that so long as protesters obtained approval in advance, demonstrations would be allowed.

docs.abstract: Oddities abound at Olympics; Beijing Games features woman with job of snaring moths that flock to beach volleyball courts; other Olympic oddities noted; photos (M)

headline.main: Movie Themes, Mascots and a Lady With a Net

docs.snippet: Human bug catchers, Madonna medleys and Sandbonies are just a few of the oddities to be found only at this year’s Olympics.
docs.lead_paragraph: In a city nowhere near the beach, inside the largest beach volleyball stadium ever constructed, there sits a small Chinese woman with a very large net. Her job during these Olympic Games consists of wielding that net to snare the moths that flock to the courts when day turns into dusk. The crowds love Ms. Bug Catcher, but then again, they love everything at beach volleyball. They find cheerleaders in bikinis there. They are taught to do the wave there and they partake as if aiming for a Guinness world record.

headline.main: An Artful Jogger in Beijing: The Pollution Is Not an Issue

docs.snippet: While these certainly are not good conditions for preparing to run a marathon  too hot and humid  they are not much worse than summer days in Princeton, N.J.
docs.lead_paragraph: Almost everything I was told about running in Beijing was wrong. My clothes would turn gray from pollution. I would be coughing and wheezing, hacking out black phlegm. I would never see any Chinese runners. I should just concentrate on getting some miles in -- there was no way I would ever be able to maintain a reasonable pace. Or maybe I should just give up and spend my time on treadmills in the gym. My goal, my coach Tom Fleming said, is just to run six or seven miles every day. I can worry about longer distances and pace when I get home.

docs.abstract: Rob Walker column on Ospop sneakers, which are made in China by Chinese workers and are based on design widely worn by Chinese laborers, but with higher-quality materials and structural improvements meant to appeal to Western consumers; interviews Ospop's founder, Ben Walters, New Jersey native who relocated to China in 2003; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: A simple shoe popular among Chinese laborers gets a style makeover for the Western consumer.
docs.lead_paragraph: With spectacular Olympic structures in Beijing like the new international airport terminal, National Stadium and the Water Cube swimming center, China projects one image to the world. In the West, at least, many observers see another image: massive air pollution and protesters hounding Olympic torchbearers. Less often seen is the Chinese worker. He or she makes a good deal of what we buy yet remains mysterious. Possibly we think of an exploited sweatshop victim. Possibly, when toy recalls flare across the news cycle, we imagine a threat to our safety. The resulting picture is both dissonant and incomplete -- and the latest chapter in a very old story of West and East. To this centuries-old narrative we can now, somewhat surprisingly, add a specific consumer product: Ospop sneakers. Yes, they're made in China by Chinese workers. But more unusually, and more to the point, they are inspired by Chinese workers. Specifically, Ospop sneakers are based on a design widely worn by such laborers, but with higher-quality materials and structural improvements meant to appeal to a Western audience -- one that is, not incidentally, willing to pay $75 for a pair of sneakers. Since forming last October, Ospop has sold more than 7,500 pairs.

docs.abstract: Beijing Olympics are hottest event of summer, drawing average audience of about 30 million nightly to NBC television, with millions more to its cable and Web site; NBC Universal paid $894 million for American television rights, and expects to realize profit of over $100 million; Games could be most watched Olympics ever, having halo effect in ratings that extends to other network programs; photo (M)

headline.main: A Surprise Winner at the Olympic Games in Beijing: NBC

docs.snippet: The Olympics has become the hottest event of the summer, drawing an average audience of about 30 million a night on NBC, far beyond the network’s expectations.

byline.original: By BILL CARTER and RICHARD SANDOMIR; Richard Sandomir contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: After a string of disappointing years in prime time, NBC executives had high hopes for a turnaround with the Beijing Olympics; but those hopes were tempered by a string of concerns. Would China display some of its repressive political tendencies and potentially embarrass NBC? Would a protest or incident mar the feel-good atmosphere? Most of all, would enough viewers show up to justify the $894 million NBC Universal paid for the American television rights?

docs.abstract: NBC's website has unprecedented amount of 2,200 hours of live Webcasts of Beijing Olympics events, but is showing 1,400 hours of events which will not be Webcast (S)

Air pollution levels in Beijing have remained unusually low as Olympic Games pass their halfway point; air quality had remained poor during period before Games; clean air is bonus for residents of Beijing, where air quality often ranks among world's worst (M)

headline.main: More than Halfway Through the Games, a Rarity for Beijing: A Breath of Fresh Air

docs.snippet: The weekend brought two of the clearest summer days in recent memory in Beijing, a city where air quality often ranks among the worst in the world.

byline.original: By JIM YARDLEY; John Branch contributed reporting

docs.lead_paragraph: Days before the opening ceremony, the Olympic Games seemed beset with problems, none potentially more worrisome than air quality. Pollution levels remained high, despite government edicts that had removed two million vehicles from city streets and shut down factories.

docs.abstract: Jeff Howard coordinates program to help US Olympic athletes navigate often-daunting crush of news media interviews that follow medal-winning performance; photos (M)
docs.snippet: At the Olympics, every moment leading to an athlete’s event is meticulously mapped. But few competitors ever plan for what may happen next.
docs.lead_paragraph: Eight hours after Dara Torres won the last of her three silver medals in swimming, all that stood between her and her mother was a malfunctioning sound system. It was 7:30 p.m., and Torres twisted her fingers and tapped her toes inside the NBC Olympic headquarters. She had checked out of her room at the Olympic Village. She had been up since 6 a.m. Oh, and she had competed in two Olympic events.

headline.main: A Medal Count That Adds Up To Little

docs.snippet: Defining success at the Olympics is a selective process that is vulnerable to spin.
docs.lead_paragraph: There is no better place in sports than the Olympics to make a sweeping generalization. Trapped inside the rings, bound by great walls of insulation, it becomes easy to convince ourselves that the psyche and well-being of a nation actually hinges upon the competitive fate of its swimmers and hurdlers.

docs.abstract: Gao Chuancai, who hoped to stage one-man rally in Beijing to protest corruption in his village of Xingyi, is detained by Chinese authorities and escorted back to Heilongjiang Province following his interview for protest permit; has been jailed dozen times during his decade-long crusade; his recent odyssey resembles journeys of several other would-be demonstrators who responded to government's notice it would permit protest zones in Beijing during Olympic Games; photo (M)

headline.main: A Would-Be Demonstrator Is Detained in China After Seeking a Protest Permit

docs.snippet: Ten days into the Games, the government has yet to permit a single demonstration in the three official protest zones and at least four would-be protesters are in custody.

byline.original: By ANDREW JACOBS; Tang Xuemei and Zhan Yingying contributed research

docs.lead_paragraph: When Gao Chuancai slipped into the capital last week hoping to stage a one-man rally against corruption in his village in northeast China, he knew his chances of success were slim. During his decade-long crusade, Mr. Gao, a 45-year-old farmer from Heilongjiang Province, had been jailed a dozen times. Two beatings by the police left him with broken bones and shattered his teeth, he said, but did little to temper his drive.
